intro: Viscum willdenowianum, commonly known as the African mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on a variety of host trees, primarily in the savannas of sub-Saharan Africa. It belongs to the family Viscaceae and is characterized by its evergreen leaves and small, white or pale yellow flowers. The plant produces berries that are toxic to many animals but serve as a food source for certain bird species, which aid in seed dispersal. Its parasitic nature allows it to derive water and nutrients from its host, while still performing photosynthesis. Viscum willdenowianum plays a significant role in the ecological dynamics of its native habitats.
